Health & Safety for Licensed Child Care Providers, Module C
Section 2: Building & Physical Premises Safety

Children and Playground Safety

  • Stay Calm
  • Comfort Children
  • Reassure Safety
  • Encourage Questions
  • Explain Event Simply
  • Acknowledge Loss
  • Limit Media
  • Express Feelings
  • Restore Routine

Stay Calm

The most important thing you can do during and after an emergency is to stay calm. Children easily pick up on and mirror the fears and anxieties of the adults around them.

Comfort Children

Make children feel safe and comfort them. Children may crave more attention and need to be held and cuddled more. Give it to them.

Reassure Safety

Reassure children that steps are being taken to keep them safe. Point out the things that are already in place to keep them safe.

Encourage Questions

Ask children if they have questions or concerns. If they ask questions, let those questions lead the conversation. If they do not have questions do not push. You have let them know it is ok to talk and they may come back to you later when they want to discuss the event.

Explain Event Simply

Explain the event as simply and directly as possible. For preschool children they may be content with just a simple explanation of what happened and how it will affect them. Older children will likely want and need additional information about the disaster and recovery efforts. If there are any tasks that you can suggest for them to do in the recovery it may be healing for them.

Acknowledge Loss

Acknowledge the losses that children are dealing with. They may have to relocate, be separated from friends, or observe their parents struggling with financial hardships. Allow children to express their sadness over these “secondary losses.”

Limit Media

Limit exposure to media coverage of the event. Graphic stories or images of the event on television, internet, radio, newspaper, and social media may frighten and stress children more. Avoid or limit children’s exposure to this.

Express Feelings

Let children express their feelings. Infants and toddlers may express their feelings by crying more, being fussy, and difficult to soothe. Toddlers may have temper tantrums and be clingy. Preschoolers and older children may need to talk about the event or draw pictures of it to express their feelings.

Restore Routine

As soon as you can, resume your regular routine. Do the activities you did before at the times you did them. Regular routines help children function better. If they do not feel up to certain activities yet do not force them. Find ways to have fun. This will also help children heal.
